message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sublingual administration is the most common route for the rapid relief of acute angina because it allows nitroglycerin to be rapidly absorbed through the oral mucosa and enter the systemic circulation quickly. Oral administration is not rapid enough to provide immediate relief, while intramuscular and intravenous injections are not commonly used for the management of stable angina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nitroglycerin given for the rapid relief of acute angina is usually administered sublingually. This is because it allows for rapid absorption into the blood vessels under the tongue, resulting in a fast onset of action. Orally, it would have to go through the digestive system, which would take longer, while intramuscular and intravenous injection are not typically used for nitroglycerin in angina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sublingual administration of nitroglycerin is the most common and effective route for rapid relief of acute angina. It has a faster onset of action as it directly enters the systemic circulation through the sublingual mucosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nitroglycerin given for the rapid relief of acute angina should be administered sublingually, as it rapidly enters the systemic circulation through the blood vessels under the tongue. Oral administration would not provide rapid relief, while intramuscular and intravenous injections are not recommended for this purpose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nitroglycerin given for the rapid relief of acute angina is most commonly administered sublingually (under the tongue) as it allows for rapid absorption into the bloodstream through the sublingual mucosa. Oral administration takes longer to take effect, while intramuscular and intravenous injection routes are not typically used for the management of stable angina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nitroglycerin given for acute angina is usually given sublingually, as it has a rapid onset of action when absorbed under the tongue. Oral, intramuscular, and intravenous routes would not provide rapid relief for acute angina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sublingual administration of nitroglycerin is the most common and rapid way to relieve acute angina as it bypasses the liver and is absorbed directly into the bloodstream. Oral, intramuscular, and intravenous routes have slower onset times.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nitroglycerin given for the rapid relief of acute angina is usually administered sublingually, as it is rapidly absorbed through the mucous membranes of the mouth and provides quick relief. Oral administration would take longer to absorb and be less effective, while intramuscular and intravenous injection are not typically used for the management of stable angina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nitroglycerin given for the rapid relief of acute angina is most commonly administered sublingually, as it allows for rapid absorption through the oral mucosa and quicker onset of action compared to oral administration. Intramuscular and intravenous injections are not typically used for the treatment of stable angina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sublingual nitroglycerin is the route of administration for rapid relief of acute angina. The patient can place a tablet under their tongue for faster absorption into the bloodstream. The other routes of administration are not as fast as sublingual administration.
